awd_titl_txt: Performance of Pressure Sensitive Adhesives on Soft and Slippery Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Pressure sensitive adhesives are a class of materials that bind to a substrate after a light external pressure has been applied. They are used extensively in daily life for adhesion to dry and rigid surfaces. These materials have not been extended to other important application areas ranging from healthcare to construction where the surfaces are soft, wet, and slippery, such as skin, tissue, or wounds. These materials are often soft and can deform under pressure. The mechanical properties of these soft materials, not just their surface, can affect the ability to adhere to that surface. This research will determine the fundamental relationships between the properties of a substrate and the performance and failure of adhesives. A better understanding of performance and failure mechanisms for adhesives on soft and wet surfaces could have important impact in industries as diverse as health or flexible wearable electronics where new innovative adhesives could open new technological applications. This work will also engage high school and undergraduates in an intensive exposure to research and materials.

The viscoelastic nature of pressure sensitive adhesives makes understanding their mechanical response challenging, especially in the limit of large strains. The project aims to provide the needed knowledge for the performance of pressure sensitive adhesives on compliant and wet surfaces by testing two scientific hypotheses. First, increasing the substrate compliance should increase the size of the dissipation zone at a crack tip, and affect the performance & mode of failure of adhesives. Second, the importance of surface energy over bulk dissipation should increase for adhesion on wet surfaces. To test these hypothesis a better fundamental understanding of stress concentration within an adhesive in stratified systems as well as of the change in their surface energy upon exposure to water will be acquired. This research systematic experimental approach is divided into three aims. (1) Develop an advanced toolkit to study the performance of pressure sensitive adhesives on soft, wet, and slippery surfaces, (2) Understand peeling adhesion of pressure sensitive adhesives from soft and wet surfaces, and (3) Characterize tack on soft and wet substrates. The outreach and educational components include a partnership with local high schools to engage students in the research experience with a focus on underrepresented students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Pressure sensitive adhesives (PSAs) are a class of glues that bind to a substrate after a light external pressure has been applied. While ubiquitous in everyday life, PSAs are very intricate materials. PSAs bear a mechanical load to maintain the adhesive bond and can sustain very large strains (>100%) prior to failure. In emerging areas, such as health care, flexible electronics, and the food industry, PSAs need to be effective on soft, wet, and slippery surfaces. The central objective for the proposed work was to understand how change in the properties of a substrate (compliant, wet) affects the performance and failure of PSAs. Our approach to answer this question was to develop a set of model materials systems to study the performance of adhesives on soft, wet, and slippery surfaces. We then characterized adhesion under wet and dry conditions and modeled the process.

 

We first investigated how the presence of water affected the adhesive properties.  Our findings showed that water remains trapped within the contact region and prevented to formation of solid-solid contact. Adhesion to surfaces like clean glass was more affected by the presence of water than adhesion to hydrophobic surfaces. Analysis of the debonding process showed that the surface energy of the PSA was higher in water than in air, therefore hydration of the PSA played an important role on adhesion. We then investigated the role of the solution pH and found that the adhesive strength also depended strongly on the pH, with the strongest adhesion at the lowest pH. Separate experiments showed that deprotonation of the acrylic acid groups in the PSA lead to a decrease in adhesion at higher pH. In the final phase of the project we investigated the role of substrate elasticity on adhesion. Our experiments showed that debonding from soft surface take much longer time than debonding on harder ones. The effect of extensional compliance on debonding can be analyzed using existing fracture mechanics frameworks. However, we observed that the mode of debonding was strongly altered when detaching from a soft surface. Our results show that the typical fingering instability observed during debonding from rigid surfaces is suppressed during adhesion to soft surfaces. A scaling argument shows that the suppression of the fingering instability is due to elastohydrodynamic deformation. Beyond the study of PSAs, the basic scientific findings from this research are expected to broadly impact technologies employing thin films, lithography, interfaces, and hydrogels. This research has also contributed to the training of future engineers with skills in the use of emerging tool for measuring and modeling hydrodynamics, contact mechanics, adhesion, and friction.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2021
Modified by: Joelle Frechette
